thread.title: Rush at US airports as fight to restore travel ban formalised
thread.title_full: Rush at US airports as fight to restore travel ban formalised

title: Rush at US airports as fight to restore travel ban formalised
text:
Map: United States 
The US Justice Department has filed a formal notice that it intends to appeal a Seattle judge's block of President Donald Trump's travel ban as visa-holders are hurrying to board US-bound flights. 
Those who could travel immediately were being urged to do so because of uncertainty over whether the Justice Department would be granted an emergency freeze of the order issued Friday. Donald Trump's executive order on immigration and its immediate consequences explained. 
Rula Aoun, director of the Arab American Civil Rights League in Dearborn, Michigan, said her group is advising people to hurry. 
"We're telling them to get on the quickest flight ASAP," said Ms Aoun, whose group filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in federal court in Detroit asking a judge to declare Mr Trump's immigration order unconstitutional. 
Ms Aoun said some people had had to make hard choices, including a Yemeni family expected to arrive at John F Kennedy International Airport on Sunday from Egypt without two of their children. 
The father and two of the children are US citizens, the mother has an immigrant visa, but the other two children did not yet have theirs and were left behind with relatives. 
"They just don't want to take a chance of waiting," she said. 
US officials have said up to 60,000 foreigners had their visas "provisionally revoked" to comply with Mr Trump's order. External Link: @realDonaldTrump: "What is our country coming to when a judge can halt a Homeland Security travel ban and anyone, even with bad intentions, can come into US? 
Confusion during the rollout of the ban initially found green card holders caught in travel limbo, until the White House on Wednesday clarified that they would be allowed to enter and leave the US as they pleased. 
Mr Trump had earlier pledged to overturn Judge James L Robart's ruling to temporarily block the immigration ban on seven Muslim majority countries. 
Judge Robart questioned the constitutionality of Mr Trump's order, while the President took to twitter calling the judgement "ridiculous" and questioned the "so-called" judge's credentials. 
The US State Department meanwhile released a statement saying that it had "reversed the provisional revocation of visas" in order to comply with the ruling. 
"Those individuals with visas that were not physically cancelled may now travel if the visa is otherwise valid," the statement said. 
ABC/wires First posted February 05, 2017 12:34:36 The Trump presidency
